description.narrative:
Miljön i Asien och Stillahavsområdet påverkas av klimatförändringar, storskaliga utvecklingsprojekt, städers utbredning, föroreningar, avskogning, vattenbrist och överfiske. Människor saknar ofta information om de miljöproblem som påverkar dem, information som skulle göra det möjligt för dem att uttrycka sin oro över negativa miljöeffekter av storskaliga projekt och att öka deras motståndskraft mot klimatpåverkan. Befintlig miljöinformation är ofta svår att förstå för allmänheten och beslutsfattare. Rösterna från de mest utsatta för klimatförändringarnas effekter - kvinnor, ungdomar och inhemska samhällen - marginaliseras och hörs sällan i lokala eller internationella medier. Miljöjournalister och lokala miljöaktivister arbetar ofta isolerat och utan stöd och kan inte koppla in i de större globala samtalen. Dessutom tenderar kommunikationsinfrastrukturen att vara dålig på lokal nivå. Media-folk saknar medel, tid och expertis och står ofta inför dåligt utrustade forskningsinstitut och motstånd från myndigheterna att tillhandahålla öppna data.
Internews Earth Journalism Network (EJN) s övergripande mål är att beslutsfattare, människor och samhällen använder ny kunskap för att utveckla bättre miljöpolicy och planer för naturresurshantering. EJN syftar till att öka kvantiteten och kvaliteten på miljörapportering i Asien-Stillahavsområdet. Tillvägagångssätten omfattar utbildningar, stipendier till större miljötoppmöten, delbidrag, stipendier och utveckling av webb för öppen data. De förväntade resultaten inkluderar: 1) Förbättrad tillförlitlig tillgång för allmänheten, samhällen och beslutsfattare till olika källor till socio-miljöinformation 2) Förbättrad mängd och kvalitet av socio-miljöinformation 3) Ökad inkludering av kvinnor och marginaliserade grupper i socio-miljömedia och information 4) Ökad kunskapsdelning och / eller samverkan kring samhälls-miljöinformation
Outputs inkluderar: - 45 Organisationsbidrag - Tilldelas lokala mediapartners, CSOs, icke-statliga organisationer eller andra gräsrotsgrupper för lokal kapacitetsuppbyggnad, nätverk, innehållsproduktion etc. - 152 Särskilda Projektutmärkelser - Beviljade bidrag till individer / grupper, frilansare, videografer, bloggare, entreprenörer, dataloggare, CSO-grupper, nystartade företag och andra "icke-uttag" -grupper som ansöker om att göra socio-miljöprojekt. - 120 Story Grants - Tilldelas individuella journalister för produktion av nyheter och särdrag. - Utbildning av tränare för 200 journalister - Att bygga lokalt ledarskap och förbättra det regionala nätverket av miljömediapartner, redaktörer, tränare och mentorer - Cirka 4000 praktikanter utbildade för att producera kvalitativ socio-miljöinformation per år - Omkring 1 000 000 publikum träffades globalt per år - Medlemmar av klimatförändringsmedier (CCMP) - utdelas varje år till ett dussin ledande journalister från regionen för att delta i och täcka de årliga klimat toppmötena för FN: s klimatkonvention, vilket gör det möjligt för dem att engagera sig på global nivå och kraftigt bygga upp sin kapacitet - GeoJournalistik - Utveckling och underhåll av regionala webbplatser som är avsedda för miljöskydd av nyckelområden, inklusive användandet av visualiserad data och andra innovativa digitala medietekniker. - Relevanta forskningsprojekt (identifierade under genomförandefasen) Sverige kommer att stödja EJN från 2017-2021, med budgeten 46 801 000 kronor.

The Asia Pacific region is impacted by environmental stress resulting from climate change, large scale development projects, urban excess, pollution, deforestation, water scarcity and overfishing among others. Communities affected often lack information of the environmental challenges they are facing which would allow them to voice their concern over the negative environmental effects of large scale projects as well as to increase their resilience to the impacts of climate change. Existing environmental information is often unintelligible to the public and policy-makers. The voices of those most vulnerable to the effects of climate change – women, youth, and indigenous communities- are marginalised and rarely heard in either local or international media. Environmental journalists and local environmental activists not seldom work in isolation and without support, and may be disconnected from larger global conversations. Moreover, communication infrastructure tends poor at local level. Media workers lack funds, time and expertise and are facing ill-equipped research institutions, or reluctance by authorities to provide open data.
Internews’ Earth Journalism Network (EJN)’s overarching goal is that policy makers, people and communities use new knowledge to develop better environmental policies and natural resource management plans. EJN aims to boost the quantity and quality of environmental media coverage in the Asia-Pacific region. The approaches include training programmes, fellowships to major environmental summits, sub-grants, story stipends, open data webpage development. The expected results includes:
1) Improved reliable access for public, communities, policy makers to diverse sources of socio-environmental information 2) Improved quantity and quality of socio-environmental information 3) Increased inclusion of women and marginalized groups in socio-environmental media and information 4) Increased peer to peer & multi-stakeholder knowledge sharing and/or collaboration around socio-environmental information
The outputs include: - 45 Organizational Grants – Awarded to local media partners, CSOs, NGOs or other grass-roots groups for local capacity-building, networking, content production, etc. - 152 Special Project Awards - grants awarded to individuals/groups, freelancers, videographers, bloggers, entrepreneurs, data journalists, CSOs groups, start-ups and other “non-outlet” groups applying to do socio-environmental projects. - 120 Story Grants – Awarded to individual journalists for production of news and feature pieces. - Training of Trainers for 200 journalists – to build local leadership and enhance the regional network of environmental media partners, editors, trainers and mentors - Around 4,000 trainees trained for producing quality socio-environmental information per year - Around 1,000,000 hits of audience reached globally per year - Climate Change Media Partnership (CCMP) Fellowships – awarded each year to a dozen leading journalists from the region to attend and cover the annual UNFCCC climate summits, enabling them to engage at the global level, and greatly build their capacity - GeoJournalism – Development and Maintenance of regional websites dedicated to environmental coverage of key regions, including the use of visualized data and other innovative digital media techniques. - Relevant research projects (identified during the implementation phase)
Sweden will support EJN from 2017-2021, with the budget as of SEK 46 801 000.

Objectives for EJN AP 2: Overall Objective: To improve governance and accountability in the Asia-Pacific region through a strengthened information ecosystem for informed decision-making and action by citizens, political leaders, and other key decision makers. Project Objective: Advance public understanding of the serious state of the environment and climate crises to drive changes that can effectively address these challenges through strengthened environmental reporting across media in the Asia-Pacific region. Intermediate-Objectives: 1. Strengthen the capacity of journalists and media organisations to produce high-quality, factual and engaging public environmental information on the consequences of human impacts on climate and the environment and provide viable solutions to respond to these impacts. 2. Increase the quantity of high-quality content and media coverage on key environmental themes -- including climate change, biodiversity loss, ocean management, wildlife trafficking, air pollution, energy transition, and sustainable development -- to focus public attention on the interdependence of the health and well-being of humans, animals, and their environments. 3. Empower women, the poor, youth, indigenous peoples, and other vulnerable groups to address the disproportionate impacts of environmental degradation by amplifying their voices in environmental reporting and increasing their access to high-quality, publicly available environmental information.

description.narrative: The annual reports for the Project covering the period 1 September 2020 – 31 December 2021 are not submitted yet until 31 March 2022, so the results to be highlighted cannot be thoroughly concluded here. Still, there have been interesting activities to be shared as followed: - In the Philippines, EJN in partnership with the Asian Center for Journalism (ACFJ) at the Ateneo De Manila University offers a First-of-its-Kind Collaborative Climate Change Reporting Course. In the past this was not readily available to most newsrooms. As the climate crisis continues to unfold, courses like this could help journalists catch up on information and to localize this knowledge for scientific- or evidence-based stories. This is a great opportunity for journalists to work together and communicate the climate crisis effectively. This course has started from March-September 2021. - In May 2021, Indonesian Journalists had the workshop on Impacts of Chinese Investment. The workshop brought together Indonesian editors, journalists and civil society groups to discuss the issues related to Chinese investments in Indonesia. According to data from Indonesia’s investment coordinating board (BKPM), China accounted for 17% of foreign direct investment in 2019 in Indonesia, the second largest after Singapore. The key challenge was the inadequacy of open data from the government, which make it difficult for journalists to access information for reporting. The workshop was an opportunity for journalists, editors and those in civil society to identify knowledge gaps in covering these issues, share ideas for collaboration and discuss how to mitigate the challenges journalists are currently facing on the ground. - On August 2, 2021, the Bhutan Media Foundation (BMF), EJN’s grantee, convened the workshop with reporters along with NGOs and other officials at a two-day workshop, ‘Linking Climate Change with Public Policies.’ The journalists presented their climate change-related stories and shared their reporting experiences during the workshop. Bhutan is considered a biodiversity hotspot, lack of funding and specialization among journalists pose limitations for reporters to write effective stories that could influence the public. With this support grant, some of the stories have been impactful in generating public discourse and bringing about policy change. For instance, freelance reporter Sonam Lhendup’s article on the danger of flashfloods in Lhuentse prompted the district disaster management committee to conduct an in-depth study and assessment on the potential risk of a glacial lake outburst flood (GLOFs) and build flood protection walls in low-lying areas. - World Environment Day on June 5th, EJN supported a wide range of activities across the region, for example building journalists’ capacity and sparking discussion around key environmental topics like wildlife trafficking, data journalism, sand mining, illegal fishing and the need to focus on youth and Indigenous communities. - In July 2021, EJN awarded Fellowships to 18 journalists in the Mekong region to enhance their data journalism skills and provide them with guidance and mentorship to report on water security and natural resources. - EJN offered grants to support the production of in-depth stories that focus on how infections like COVID-19 spread from animals to humans and on efforts to prevent future outbreaks by improving human, animal and environmental health. The application was just closed by 15 August 2021. - EJN is offering grants to journalists from Bangladesh and India to report on the impacts of climate change on human health along the Bay of Bengal coast. EJN focus on stories that report on potential solutions and address how vulnerable communities are responding to challenges. The application will be closed by August 29. - E-learning course for journalists to improve their reporting on zoonotic diseases and their environmental origins is launched on their website: Zoonotic Disease Training for Journalists (thinkific.com)
